awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Discrepancy to Optimization and Approximations in Geometric Hypergraphs
awd_abstract_narration:
How does one evenly distribute points on a sphere?  Given points, how does one color them red and blue, so no circular region has too many of one color? The first question is open-ended until one defines evenly; the second is fully-specified, but hard -- there are many possible colorings and many regions to check. In these, and many similar problems, even when one is trying to be fair to a number of players, some will win a little and some will lose a little; the mathematical concept of "discrepancy" captures the amount of deviation from uniformity that must occur.  Through what sometimes seem abstract problems, such as coloring, this mathematics explores the limits of how well can a sample represent a whole -- an important question for computation, since algorithms are often made efficient by doing initial computation on a sample of the input data. 

In this project, the PI will explore questions of geometric discrepancy and their connections to algorithms for optimization and approximation. She has three foci: (1) Relative discrepancy, in which bounds depend on set size -- eg., the number of points in a circle. (In two and three dimensions, the PI has previously nearly optimal bounds in two- and three-dimensions.) Algorithms to find good colorings will also be sought, especially for geometric objects with characteristics (like "fatness") that apply to models for manufacturing or simulation.  (2) Extending epsilon-nets, which are samples that approximate a whole (e.g., a subset S from points P is an epsilon-net if any circle that contains an epsilon fraction of P must contain a point of S) so that you have some idea how many points from S lie in a circle that contains a larger fraction of P. Epsilon-nets not only help approximate a whole, but also indicate where more computation is needed in divide and conquer algorithms. (3) Leveraging improved epsilon nets for better approximation algorithms. It has been known for some time that improved bounds on epsilon nets in various geometric settings (e.g. axis aligned rectangles, etc) immediately give improved bounds for various NP-hard packing and covering problems in those same geometric settings. The PI has some of the strongest bounds (e.g. she proved optimal bounds in the case of axis-aligned rectangles, and has also found some practical applications of these to problems in networking), and aims to make progress on a number of still open questions in this domain, such as the size of weak epsilon-nets for axis aligned rectangles. 

This work pulls together several themes in mathematics and computation, including when local solutions can be extended to global solutions.  Progress in understanding discrepancy can have broad and unexpected impact: fairness of resource allocation affects more than just science and engineering simulations.

por.por_cntn:
Computational geometry is pervasive, from range searching problems (e.g., what objects are within a quarter mile of a given point) to eliminating depth cycles (a problem inspired by a rendering algorithm in computer graphics), to point-location in geometric arrangements (locate a query point within a spacesubdivision induced by a set of geometric objects).

An important notion in discrete and computational geometry is that of geometric discrepancy. The notion of discrepancy means ``disagreement'' between an ideal scenario and an actual one.In particular, in geometric computing, discrepancy appears as a main tool to obtain approximations. This is due to the necessity to represent well a large collection of objects by a relatively small sample. For example, suppose that we are given a set of points in the plane and we wish to extract a small sample of them in order to approximate well the number of points contained in an arbitrary disk (returning to the question above "what objects are within a quarter mile of a given point?"). Such a machinery is called "approximate range search", and samples of the above kind are called "epsilon-approximations". These structures have been originally introduced in learning theory, but discrepancy is a main tool in reducing their complexity. In order to minimize geometric discrepancy bounds one often needs to connect the geometric structure imposed by the geometric setup with tools from probability, combinatorics, information theory (e.g., use entropy functions), as well as empirical processes and learning theory.

The work on this project began with the study of discrepancy, in particular, discrepancy for low-degree set systems. The application of discrepancy to (approximate) range searching is important and interesting in its own right. In a wider context, range searching problems in computational geometry have been studied for almost three decades, their study was flourishing during the 90's, where the structure of "'epsilon-cuttings" (a special kind of epsilon-nets) was developed, as well as several structural properties on geometric arrangements. In spite of this progress, some fundamental problems remained unsolved (or resulted in suboptimal solutions). This was mainly due to the fact that the approach in such solutions exploited the combinatorial structure, whereas the geometric properties were used in a somewhat limited way (e.g., lines in the plane could be replaced by "pseudo-lines", and still achieve the same results about range searching). This raised the necessity to establish a new approach based on the geometry of the setup. The work on this project suggests such an approach, which integrates new tools from real algebraic geometry. As the outcomes of this project show, using these tools we were able to obtain efficient algorithms yielding better range searching and point location machineries than those previously achieved in "traditional" computational geometry.

The theoretical work on this project led to several papers, beginning with the study of discrepancy in low degree set systems, exploiting techniques from probability and combinatorics, and then the study of point location in high-dimensional arrangementsand in the RAM model and in the decision tree model, where the latter had a direct implication to the notorious k-SUM problem in theoretical computer science. Our point-location data structure yields the currently best know query time, for arbitrary hyperplanes in d-space.  The techniques we used were based on random sampling (we exploited epsilon-cuttings) and the combinatorial structure resulting from the geometric setup, for example, one of our key results was a new combinatorial bound on the "vertical decomposition" in high-dimensional hyperplane arrangements. On a different angle, when we would like to reduce the storage complexity for point-location, we had to resort to a different approach using tools from real algebraic geometry, where we replaced vertical decompositions with polynomial partitions. In spite it is known that such partitions exist, it was unknown whether one can construct them efficiently. We established new algorithms, integrating tools from real algebraic geometry with epsilon-approximations and epsilon-cuttings (two main structures studied in this project), resulting in an efficient construction of polynomial partitioning. Our first work in this study addresses the setting of algebraic curves in 3-space, and, as a result, shows an efficient solution to the problem of eliminating depth cycles. Our second work in this study shows an efficient construction for general partitioning polynomials, as a result, we show an improved point-location data structure, an efficient range-searching machinery, and a few related results. Expanding the scope of non-uniform algorithms beyond the k-SUM problem, using the polynomial method we obtained efficient non-uniform algorithms for a few geometric problems, including collinearity testing and triangle similarity. 


Results from this project were published in top venues in discrete and computational geometry, and theoretical computer science.

The project trained one postdoc researcher, who worked on the probabilistic method in combinatorics, and eight graduate students, who worked on different graph theoretical problems, as well as matroids, convex geometry, and high-dimensional polytopes.
